tit.cmt: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takahito→Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Takahito

sen.j: 有栖川宮幟仁親王（ありすがわのみや たかひとしんのう、文化 (元号)9年1月5日（1812年2月17日） - 明治19年（1886年1月24日））は幕末・明治期の日本の皇族。
sen.e: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takahito (February 17, 1812-January 24, 1886) was a member of the imperial family from the end of Edo period to Meiji period.
Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takahito (February 17, 1812-January 24, 1886) was a member of the imperial family from the end of Edo period to Meiji period.
Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Takahito (February 17, 1812 - January 24, 1886) was a member of the imperial family from the end of Edo period to Meiji period.
sen.cmt: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takahito→Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Takahitoスペース補足

sen.j: 有栖川宮韶仁親王の第一王子。
sen.e: He was the first prince of Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Tsunahito.
He was the first prince of Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Tsunahito.
He was the first son of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tsunahito.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 妃は、左大臣二条斉信の娘・広子。
sen.e: His wife was Koshi, a daughter of Narinobu NIJYO who was the sadaijin (Minister of the left).
sen.cmt: 広子→読み方不明ですが暫定的にKoshi と訳出しています。（Web には未登録です）
sen.e: His wife was Koshi, the daughter of Narinobu NIJYO who was the sadaijin (Minister of the left).
His wife was Koshi, who was a daughter of the Sadaijin (Minister of the Left) Narinobu NIJO.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その他に数人の側室がおり、長男の有栖川宮熾仁親王・四男の有栖川宮威仁親王ともに別々の側室との間に儲けた子である。
sen.e: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Tsunahito had several concubines; he had his eldest son, Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito and his fourth son, Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takehito with different concubines.
sen.cmt: また、上記三者は、それぞれに英文の語順が異なるのですが、今回はWebの訳語に準拠しました。本来は語順の統一が望ましいかと思われます。→9/24メールでの指示で左記のとおり変更・統一されました。用語をコメント欄からterms欄へ移動しました。
sen.e: Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Tsunahito had several concubines; he had his eldest son, Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito and his fourth son, Arisugawanomiya Imperial Prince Takehito with different concubines.

He also had several concubines, and the mother of his first son later called Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito was a different consubine from the mother of his fourth son later called Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Takahito.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 幼児期は八穂宮（やほのみや）と称した。
sen.e: He was referred to as Yaho no miya when he was young.
He was referred to as Yaho no miya when he was young.
His childhood name was Yahonomiya.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 文政5年11月15日（1823年12月27日）、光格天皇の猶子となり、同6年9月23日（1823年10月26日）、12歳（数え）で親王宣下、幟仁の名を受け、翌月元服する。
sen.e: He was adopted by Emperor Kokaku on December 27, 1823, and was announced as the imperial prince and named as Takahito on October 26, 1823 at the age of 12 years old; he went through the coming-of-age ritual in the following month.
sen.cmt: 「元服する」は「元服式を行った」と考え左記のように訳出しました。
sen.e: He was adopted by Emperor Kokaku on December 27, 1823, and was announced as the imperial prince and named Takahito on October 26, 1823, at the age of 12 years old; he went through the coming-of-age ritual in the following month.

He was adopted by Emperor Kokaku on December 27, 1822, and then he was declared to be Imperial Prince Takahito at the age of 12 (by the old Japanese system) on October 26, 1823 and he had a ceremony of attaining manhood in the following month.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 弘化4年8月4日（1847年9月13日）、二品に叙せられ中務卿に任命される。
sen.e: On September 13, 1847, he was awarded nihon (the second court rank for Imperial Princes), and was assigned to Nakatsukasa-kyo (Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs).
On September 13, 1847, he was awarded nihon (the second court rank for Imperial Princes), and was assigned to Nakatsukasa-kyo (Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs).
On September 13, 1847, he was awarded the rank of Nihon (Second Order for an Imperial Prince) and assigned the position of Nakatsukasa-kyo (Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 文久3年5月20日（1863年7月5日）、猿ヶ辻（禁裏の北東）にあった有栖川宮邸前で、姉小路公知が殺害される事件が発生している。
sen.e: On July 5, 1863, there was an incident in which Kintomo ANEGAKOJI was killed in front of the residence of Arisugawanomiya that was located in Saru ga Tsuji (Northeast of the imperial palace).
On July 5, 1863, there was an incident in which Kintomo ANEGAKOJI was killed in front of the residence of Arisugawanomiya that was located in Saru ga Tsuji (Northeast of the imperial palace).

On July 5, 1863, there was an incident in which Kintomo ANEGAKOJI was killed in front of the Arisugawanomiya residence which was located near the Saru-ga-tsuji Crossroads (in the northeast of the Imperial Palace).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）5月には、熾仁親王とともに国事御用掛に任命された。
sen.e: In May in 1864, he and Imperial Prince Taruhito were assigned to Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of the State affair).
sen.cmt: 熾仁親王→Webでは、Prince Taruhito と登録されていますが親王ですので Imperial Prince Taruhito かと思われます。
sen.e: In May in 1864, he and Imperial Prince Taruhito were assigned to Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affairs).
In June 1864, he and Imperial Prince Taruhito were appointed as the Kokuji Goyogakari (the general officials of the Imperial Household in charge of state affairs).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、直後に禁門の変が発生。
sen.e: However, the Kinmon Incident occurred just after that.
However, the Kinmon Incident occurred just after that.
However, the Kinmon Incident occurred just after that.

sen.j: その前日に熾仁親王が長州の復権と松平容保の洛外追放を訴えて御所内で周旋活動をした。
sen.e: On the previous day, Imperial Prince Taruhito carried out a procurement campaign in the imperial palace appealing for restoration of the Chosu clan and an exile of Katamori MATSUDAIRA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the previous day, Imperial Prince Taruhito carried out a procurement campaign in the imperial palace appealing for restoration of the Chosu clan and the exile of Katamori MATSUDAIRA.
On the previous day, Imperial Prince Taruhito carried out a procurement campaign at the Imperial Palace to appeal for the restoration of the Choshu clan and the exile of Katamori MATSUDAIRA.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: このことにより、有栖川宮家は長州との通謀疑惑をかけられ、幟仁親王・熾仁親王父子は孝明天皇によって国事御用掛を罷免された上、謹慎および蟄居を命じられた。
sen.e: Through this act, Arisugawanomiya family was suspected for collusion with Chosu, Imperial Prince Takahito, Imperial Prince Taruhito and his father were ordered to stay and to be confined in their house, with the post of Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of the State affair) stripped, by Emperor Komei.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Through this act, the Arisugawanomiya family was suspected of collusion with Chosu, Imperial Prince Takahito, Imperial Prince Taruhito, and his father were ordered to stay and were confined in their house, with the post of Kokuji goyogakari (a general official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affairs) stripped, by Emperor Komei.

This made the Imperial Court suspect a secret relation between the Arisugawanomiya family and the Choshu clan, and consequently, Emperor Komei dismissed Imperial Prince Takahito and Imperial Prince Taruhito from their Kokuji Goyogakari position and also told them to stay at home to restrain their social activities.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: この期間中、猿ヶ辻の邸宅は京都御所拡張のために召し上げられ、幟仁親王は現在の京都市立銅駝美術工芸高等学校の場所にあった宮家の夷川別邸に転居した。
sen.e: During this period, the residence in Saru ga Tsuji were confiscated in order to extend Kyoto Imperial Palace, Imperial Prince Takahito moved to the Ebisugawa Villa of Miyake (families allowed to be in status of Imperial family) which was located in present-day Kyoto City Dohda Senior High School of Arts.

During this period, the residence in Saru ga Tsuji was confiscated in order to extend the Kyoto Imperial Palace, Imperial Prince Takahito moved to the Ebisugawa Villa of Miyake (families allowed the status of the Imperial family) which was located in present-day Kyoto City Dohda Senior High School of Arts.

During this period, the residence near the Saru-ga-tsuji Crossroads was confiscated in order to expand the Kyoto Imperial Palace, and Imperial Prince Takahito had to move to the family's secondary residence called the Ebisugawa Villa, whose site is currently used for Kyoto City Dohda Senior High School of Arts.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 慶応3年1月15日（1867年2月19日）、明治天皇の践祚に伴い処分が解かれたが、幟仁親王はこれ以降政治的な表舞台には姿をあらわさず、打診された国事御用掛への復職も辞退している。
sen.e: On February 19 in 1867, he was released from the disciplinary action due to accession (to the throne) of Emperor Meiji; since then, Imperial Prince Takahito didn't make his appearance and was never involved in politics publicly, declining their offer to let him come back to the post of Kokuji goyogakari.

On February 19 in 1867, he was released from disciplinary action due to accession (to the throne) of Emperor Meiji; since then, Imperial Prince Takahito didn't make his appearance and was never involved in politics publicly, declining offers to return to the post of Kokuji goyogakari.

On February 19, 1867, Imperial Prince Takahito was forgiven in accordance with Emperor Meiji's accession to the throne, but he never returned to the political stage from that time onward and he even declined a reinstatement offer for the Kokuji Goyogakari position.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その後、慶応3年12月20日（1868年1月14日）に一品に叙せられている。
sen.e: After that, he was awarded Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) on January 14, 1868; he returned his rank as Nakatsukasa-kyo on August 19, 1869 due to the abolishment of the official system in Japan.

After that, he was awarded Ippon (First Order of an Imperial Prince) on January 14, 1868; he returned to his rank as Nakatsukasa-kyo on August 19, 1869 due to the abolishment of the official system in Japan.
After that, he was awarded Ippon (the First Order of Imperial Prince) on January 14, 1868.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外対処、原文を分割、原文の文末を修正。

sen.j: しかし、中務卿の位は、日本の官制の廃止に伴って明治2年7月12日（1869年8月19日）に返上している。
sen.e: However, he returned his Nakatsukasa-kyo (the Minister of the Ministry of Central Affairs) position on August 19, 1869, in accordance with the abolishment of the Japanese old regulations for governmental organizations.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。一原文一訳文例外対処、原文を分割、原文の文頭を修正。

sen.j: 王政復古の大号令によって熾仁親王は新政府の総裁職に就任したが、幟仁親王も慶応4年2月20日（1868年3月13日）に議定に任命された。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Taruhito assumed the post of the president of the new government by the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule; Imperial Prince Takahito was also assigned to gijo (official post) on March 13, 1868.

Imperial Prince Taruhito assumed the post of the president of the new government by the Decree (of 1867) for the Restoration of Imperial Rule; Imperial Prince Takahito was also assigned to gijo (official post) on March 13, 1868.

Imperial Prince Taruhito assumed the president of the new government under the Decree for the Restoration of Imperial Rule, and Imperial Prince Takahito was also assigned to a gijo (senior councilor) on March 13, 1868.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: しかし政治的な役割は熾仁親王に託し、自らは表立った活動をしないまま議定職の廃止を迎えた。
sen.e: However, he delegated political roles to Imperial Prince Taruhito without publicly performing his role himself, and gijo post was abolished.
However, he delegated political roles to Imperial Prince Taruhito without publicly performing the role himself, and the gijo post was abolished.
However, he delegated political roles to Imperial Prince Taruhito without publicly performing the role himself, and the gijo post was abolished.

sen.j: 幟仁親王は政治から距離を置く代わりに、慶応4年1月17日（1868年2月10日）に神祇官総督に就任したのを皮切りに国家神道や国学の普及に努めた。
sen.e: Instead of keeping distance from politics, Imperial Prince Takahito started to be involved in disseminating state shinto or the study of Japanese classical literature when he assumed the post as the governor of Jingikan (department of worship) on February 10, 1868

Instead of keeping a distance from politics, Imperial Prince Takahito started to become involved in disseminating state Shinto or the study of Japanese classical literature when he assumed the post as the governor of Jingikan (department of worship) on February 10, 1868

Keeping a distance from politics, Imperial Prince Takahito started to become involved in the dissemination of State Shinto and the study of Japanese classical literature as soon as he assumed the post of the governor general of the Jingikan (the department of worship) on February 10, 1868.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Intead を使うと、意味が変わってくると思うので省きました。

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）7月25日、家督を熾仁親王に譲り正式に隠居した後も、神道総裁や皇典講究所（國學院大學の前身）総裁などを歴任した。
sen.e: He served in various positions such as the governor of Shinto and the governor of Koten Kokyusho; an research institute for Shinto sect (predecessor to the current Kokugakuin University) after he delegated his post as the reigns of the family to Imperial Taruhito for his retirement.

He served in various positions, such as governor of Shinto and governor of Koten Kokyusho; an research institute for the Shinto sect (predecessor to the current Kokugakuin University) later he delegated his post giving the reigns of the family to Imperial Taruhito because of his retirement.

After he stepped down from his position as the head of the family and Imperial Prince Taruhito officially succeeded the family on September 9, 1871, he still held various positions such as the governor of Shinto and the controller general of the Research Institute for the Japanese Classics (the forerunner of present-day Kokugakuin University).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 一方で仏教への理解も厚く、各地の名刹に書や物品を下賜している。
sen.e: On the other hand, he understood Buddhism well; he granted documents or goods to famous temples.
He understood Buddhism well; and granted documents or goods to famous temples.
He had a deep understanding of Buddhism as well, and he granted documents and commodities to famous temples.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 幟仁親王は維新以後の急速な生活様式の欧米化に対して消極的であった。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Takahito was not inclined to actively introduce the westernized life style that was rapidly introduced after the Meiji Restoration.
Imperial Prince Takahito was not inclined to actively introduce the westernized life style that was being rapidly introduced after the Meiji Restoration.
People's lifestyle rapidly became Westernized after the Meiji Restoration, but Imperial Prince Takahito displayed a negative attitude toward this movement.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: すでに皇室の公式行事では洋式の大礼服を着用する事が義務付けられていたが、生涯を通じて洋装を拒んだ幟仁親王だけは特例として明治天皇から束帯での参加を許されていた。
sen.e: Wearing a western style full-dress suit had been already required in official events of the Imperial Household, Imperial Prince Takahito who refused to wear western clothe throughout his life was exclusively allowed to participate in a such event wearing sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) by Emperor Meiji.

Wearing a western style full-dress suit had been already required in official events of the Imperial Household, Imperial Prince Takahito who refused to wear western clothing throughout his life was exclusively allowed to participate in a such events wearing sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress) by Emperor Meiji.

Although people were required to be in full western dress in official events at the Imperial Court at that time, Emperor Meiji allowed Imperial Prince Takahito, who refused to wear Western-style clothes throughout his life, to attend events in Sokutai (traditional Japanese formal court dress) as an exception.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。「洋式の」の訳、｢束帯」という言葉を入れたほうがよいと思います。

sen.j: また、終生髷を切らず、西洋の薬も一切口にしなかった。
sen.e: He didn't cut his topknot, and never took western medicine throughout his life.
He didn't cut his topknot, and never took western medicine throughout his life.
He didn't cut his topknot, and never took western medicine throughout his life.

sen.j: その一方、オルゴールや洋時計などの蒐集を趣味としていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, he enjoyed collecting music boxes and western clocks.
Meanwhile, he enjoyed collecting music boxes and western clocks.
Meanwhile, he enjoyed collecting music boxes and western clocks.

sen.j: 有栖川宮家の歴代当主同様、書道および歌道の達人であり、第五代・有栖川宮職仁親王によってあみ出された、いわゆる「有栖川流書道」を大成させた。
sen.e: He was an expert of calligraphy and waka poetry as well as the heads of Arisugawanomiya family in the past, and achieved success in so-called `Arisugawa school of calligraphy' which was developed by the fifth Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.

He was an expert at calligraphy and waka poetry like the heads of Arisugawanomiya family in the past, and achieved success in so-called `Arisugawa school of calligraphy' which was developed by the fifth Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.

He was an expert at calligraphy and waka poetry like the heads of Arisugawanomiya family in the past, and achieved success in so-called `Arisugawa school of calligraphy' which was developed by the fifth Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Taruhito.

sen.j: さらに、昭憲皇太后に歌道を、明治天皇に書道と歌道を指南したほか、五箇条の御誓文の正本も幟仁親王によって揮毫されている。
sen.e: Besides, he instructed Empress Dowager Shoken in waka poetry, and Emperor Meiji in calligraphy and waka poetry; he also wrote the original document of `Charter Oath of Five Articles'.
Besides, instructing the Empress Dowager Shoken in waka poetry, and Emperor Meiji in calligraphy and waka poetry; he also wrote the original document of `Charter Oath of Five Articles'.

In addition, he instructed Empress Dowager Shoken in waka poetry and also instructed Emperor Meiji in calligraphy and waka poetry, and moreover, he wrote the original document of Charter Oath of Five Articles.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 明治19年（1886年）1月24日、幟仁親王は危篤に陥った。
sen.e: On January 24, Imperial Prince Takahito failed into critical condition.

sen.e: On January 24, Imperial Prince Takahito fell into critical condition.
On January 24, 1886, Imperial Prince Takahito fell critically ill.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: その報を知った明治天皇は急ぎ大勲位に叙し大勲位菊花大綬章を授けた。
sen.e: Having heard this, Emperor Meiji awarded him Supreme Order, and granted Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.

sen.e: Having heard this, Emperor Meiji awarded him the Supreme Order, and granted Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
On hearing this, Emperor Meiji awarded him the Supreme Order and the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 同日、73歳で薨去。
sen.e: On that day, he passed away at the age of 73 years old.
On that day, he passed away at the age of 73 years old.
He passed away the same day at the age of 73 years old.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 豊島岡墓地に埋葬された。
sen.e: He was laid to rest in Toshimagaoka Cemetery.
He was laid to rest in Toshimagaoka Cemetery.
